newsitem.title: JAPAN: Nissan forms new Peru sales unit.
newsitem.headline: Nissan forms new Peru sales unit.

text.p: Nissan Motor Co Ltd said on Friday it has set up a new distribution company in Lima, Peru, integrating its former importing unit.
The new company, Nissan Maquinarias S.A., capitalised at 43.45 million sol, (1.8 billion yen), is owned 80 percent by Maquinarias S.A., and 10 percent each by Nissan and Marubeni Corp.

Nissan Motor del Peru S.A., Nissan's import and wholesale unit in Peru, previously imported Mexican-made Sentra cars and pickup trucks and some Japanese-made vehicles for marketing through Maquinarias's sales outlets, a Nissan spokeswoman said.
Overall car sales in Peru stood at 38,310 units in 1995, up 24 percent from a year earlier, including 5,988 Nissan cars which held a 15.6 percent share.

Nissan Maquinarias has set a sales target of 10,000 in 1998 by introduction of new models, aiming at a 22 percent share. Nissan introduced the new Terrano II, made by Nissan's Spanish unit, in November, and new Japanese-made Pathfinder heavy sport-utility vehicle in April.
